stem: A 45-year-old client is admitted for a diagnostic workup of frequent 'pounding' headaches and diaphoresis. Based on the documentation in the Serial Catecholamine & Hemodynamic Log, which finding indicates a Pheochromocytoma crisis?

tabs.title: Metabolic & Urine Labs
tabs.content:
24-Hour Urine: Vanillylmandelic Acid (VMA) 18 mg/24h (Normal < 7). Metanephrines 4.2 mg/24h (Normal < 1.3).
Serum: Norepinephrine 2,400 pg/mL (High).

tabs.title: Nursing Assessment
tabs.content: Current: Client reports sudden 'terror' and sense of impending doom. Skin is pale and drenched in sweat. Physical exam reveals a palpable mass on the left flank; BP spiked immediately after palpation.

options.text: The paroxysmal hypertension (242/134) Following abdominal palpation
The Metanephrine urine level of 4.2 mg/24h
The patient's report of a pounding headache
The presence of diaphoresis during the attack

rationale.correct: This is a **Pheochromocytoma Crisis (a1)**. A pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor of the adrenal medulla. The most critical cue is the **paroxysmal (sudden) hypertension** triggered by **abdominal palpation**, which physically 'squeezes' the tumor and releases a massive surge of adrenaline. This represents a major safety riskâ€”nurses should **never** palpate the abdomen of a patient with suspected pheochromocytoma.
clinicalPearls: VMA and Metanephrines are breakdown products of catecholamines used for diagnosis.
Treatment involves Alpha-blockers (Phenoxybenzamine) BEFORE Beta-blockers to prevent unopposed alpha vasoconstriction.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing the lab value (a2) as the 'indicator of crisis.'
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Labs confirm the *diagnosis*, but the **BP spike triggered by palpation** is the clinical *crisis* and safety education point the NCLEX prioritizes.

mnemonic.title: No Touchy
mnemonic.expansion: Pheochromocytoma: High BP, pounding head. Touch the belly? They're nearly dead.
